item.title: Forecasting S&P 500 Returns with R (Part 1)
item.description: Disclaimer: I am not a data scientist, but I am an R, investing, and data science enthusiast. 1. Introduction Is it possible to predict stock returns? item.title: Optimal Portfolio Construction
item.description: Optimal Portfolio Construction In this article we will compare several portfolio construction methodologies. We will evaluate the Modern Portfolio Theory and the Risk Parity portfolio and Resampled Efficient Frontier approaches. The Modern Portfolio Theory approach attempts to maximize the return of a group of assets (a portfolio) for the level of risk borne by those assets. One complaint of this approach is its tendency to lead to overconcentrated portfolios.

item.title: Finding Distressed Stocks
item.description: Finding Stocks at Risk of Financial Distress The goal of this analysis is to isolate stocks that are particularly risky to the long-only investor. A probability of distress will be computed based on observable financial data. The model was derived in academia and later utilized in a book titled “Quantitative Value” (2013). The Formula Logit Probability of Financial Distress (LPFD) A logistic regression model is used to estimate whether a firm is in financial distress or not.
